trans-unit.source: Represents a list of items and tasks displayed as a menu on a [!INCLUDE[win7](~/add/includes/win7-md.md)] taskbar button.
The [!INCLUDE[win7](~/add/includes/win7-md.md)] taskbar provides enhanced functionality for starting programs directly from the taskbar button by using Jump Lists.
Jump Lists are also used in the [!INCLUDE[win7](~/add/includes/win7-md.md)] Start menu.
You access a Jump List by right-clicking a taskbar button or by clicking the arrow next to a program in the Start menu.
For more information about Jump Lists, see the [Taskbar](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=178478) section of the Windows User Experience Interaction Guidelines.

The JumpList class provides a managed wrapper for the Jump List functionality in the [!INCLUDE[win7](~/add/includes/win7-md.md)] taskbar and manages the data passed to the [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_mswin](~/add/includes/tlasharptla-mswin-md.md)] shell.

The functionality exposed by the JumpList class is not available in versions of [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_mswin](~/add/includes/tlasharptla-mswin-md.md)] earlier than [!INCLUDE[win7](~/add/includes/win7-md.md)].
Applications that use the JumpList class will run in other versions of [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_mswin](~/add/includes/tlasharptla-mswin-md.md)], but the Jump List will not be available.
For more information about the Windows shell and native Jump List APIs, see [Taskbar Extensions](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=178479).
The following illustration shows the Jump List for Windows Media Player, with items in the **Tasks** and **Frequent** categories.

![Windows Media Player Jump List](~/add/media/wpfshell-jumplist.png "Windows Media Player Jump List") Windows Media Player Jump List ## Configuring a Jump List Jump Lists can contain two types of items, a <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> and a <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpPath>.
A <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> is a link to a program and a <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpPath> is a link to a file.

You can visually separate items in a Jump List by creating a <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> that does not have a <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask.Title%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpItem.CustomCategory%2A> specified.
This empty <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> will be displayed as a horizontal line in the Jump List.
> [!NOTE] > If the type of the file specified in a <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpPath> is not registered with your application, the file will not appear in the Jump List.
For example, if you add a <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpPath> that points to a .txt file, your application must be registered to handle .txt files.
For more information, see [Introduction to File Associations](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=178480).
Jump items are placed into categories in the JumpList.
By default, a <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpItem> is displayed in the **Tasks** category.
Alternatively, you can specify a <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpItem.CustomCategory%2A> for the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpItem>.

You can specify whether the standard **Recent** and **Frequent** categories are displayed in the JumpList by setting the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList.ShowRecentCategory%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList.ShowFrequentCategory%2A> properties.
The contents of these categories are managed by the [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_mswin](~/add/includes/tlasharptla-mswin-md.md)] shell.
Because these categories might contain much of the same data, you typically display one or the other in your JumpList, but not both.

[!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_mswin](~/add/includes/tlasharptla-mswin-md.md)] automatically manages recent items if they are opened through a common file dialog box or used to open an application through file type association.

When an item is accessed through the Jump List, you can notify the [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_mswin](~/add/includes/tlasharptla-mswin-md.md)] shell to add the item to the **Recent** category by calling the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList.AddToRecentCategory%2A> method.
Applying a Jump List to the Windows Shell You cannot access the shellâ€™s Jump List directly or read its contents into the JumpList class.
Instead, the JumpList class provides a representation of a Jump List that you can work with, and then apply to the [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_mswin](~/add/includes/tlasharptla-mswin-md.md)] shell.
You typically create a JumpList and set it one time when the application is first run.
However, you can modify or replace the JumpList at run time.
When you have set the JumpList properties, you must apply the JumpList to the Windows shell before its contents appear in the taskbar Jump List.
This is done automatically when the JumpList is first attached to an application, either in XAML or in a call to the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList.SetJumpList%2A> method.
If you modify the contents of the JumpList at run time, you must call the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList.Apply%2A> method to apply its current contents to the Windows shell.
Setting a Jump List in XAML A JumpList is not automatically attached to an <xref:System.Windows.Application> object.
You attach a JumpList to an <xref:System.Windows.Application> object in XAML by using the attached property syntax.
The JumpList class implements the <xref:System.ComponentModel.ISupportInitialize> interface to support XAML declaration of a JumpList.

If the JumpList is declared in XAML and attached to the current <xref:System.Windows.Application>, it is automatically applied to the [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_mswin](~/add/includes/tlasharptla-mswin-md.md)] shell when the JumpList is initialized.

Setting and Modifying a Jump List in Code You attach a JumpList to an <xref:System.Windows.Application> object in code by calling the static <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList.SetJumpList%2A> method.
This also applies the JumpList to the [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_mswin](~/add/includes/tlasharptla-mswin-md.md)] shell.
To modify a JumpList at run time, you call the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList.GetJumpList%2A> method to get the JumpList that is currently attached to an <xref:System.Windows.Application>.
After you have modified the properties of the JumpList, you must call the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList.Apply%2A> method to apply the changes to the Windows shell.
> [!NOTE] > You typically create one JumpList that is attached to the <xref:System.Windows.Application> and applied to the [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_mswin](~/add/includes/tlasharptla-mswin-md.md)] shell.
However, you can create multiple JumpList objects.

Only one JumpList at a time can be applied to the [!INCLUDE[TLA#tla_mswin](~/add/includes/tlasharptla-mswin-md.md)] shell, and only one JumpList at a time can be associated with an <xref:System.Windows.Application>.
The .NET Framework does not require that these be the same JumpList.
> [!NOTE] > This class contains a link demand at the class level that applies to all members.
A <xref:System.Security.SecurityException> is thrown when the immediate caller does not have full-trust permission.
For more information about security demands, see [Link Demands](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md) and [Inheritance Demands](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/28b9adbb-8f08-4f10-b856-dbf59eb932d9).
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Shell.JumpList"></xref> class.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Shell.JumpList"></xref> class with the specified parameters.
The **Recent** and **Frequent** categories often contain many of the same jump items.
As a result, applications typically display either the **Recent** or the **Frequent** category in the Jump List, but not both.
The collection of <xref href="System.Windows.Shell.JumpItem"></xref> objects that are displayed in the Jump List.
A value that indicates whether frequently used items are displayed in the Jump List.
A value that indicates whether recently used items are displayed in the Jump List.
Adds the specified item path to the **Recent** category of the Jump List.
The contents of the **Recent** category are managed by the Windows shell.
To display recently used items in the Jump List, set the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList.ShowRecentCategory%2A> property to `true`.
You can call the AddToRecentCategory method to request that the Windows shell add an item path to the **Recent** items list.
If your application is not registered to handle the file type of the item, it will not appear in the **Recent** list and calls to AddToRecentCategory will fail silently.
The path to add to the Jump List.
Adds the specified jump path to the **Recent** category of the Jump List.
The contents of the **Recent** category are managed by the Windows shell.
To display recently used items in the Jump List, set the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList.ShowRecentCategory%2A> property to `true`.
You can call the AddToRecentCategory method to request that the Windows shell add the specified jump path to the **Recent** items list.
If your application is not registered to handle the file type of the item, it will not appear in the **Recent** list and calls to AddToRecentCategory will fail silently.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Shell.JumpPath"></xref> to add to the Jump List.
Adds the specified jump task to the **Recent** category of the Jump List.
The contents of the **Recent** category are managed by the Windows shell.
To display recently used items in the Jump List, set the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList.ShowRecentCategory%2A> property to `true`.
You can call the AddToRecentCategory method to request that the Windows shell add the specified jump task to the **Recent** items list.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask"></xref> to add to the Jump List.
Sends the <xref href="System.Windows.Shell.JumpList"></xref> to the Windows shell in its current state.
The Apply method sends the content of the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList> to the Windows shell in its current state.
After this call is complete, the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList.JumpItems%2A> property is modified to contain only those items that the Windows shell successfully added to its taskbar Jump List.
You can access the lists of removed items through event handlers for the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList.JumpItemsRejected> and <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList.JumpItemsRemovedByUser> events.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Shell.JumpList"></xref> is not completely initialized.
Signals the start of the <xref href="System.Windows.Shell.JumpList"></xref> initialization.
The <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList> class implements the <xref:System.ComponentModel.ISupportInitialize> interface to support XAML declaration of a <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList>.
The BeginInit method is only called when the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList> is declared in XAML and attached to an <xref:System.Windows.Application> by using the attached property syntax.
You do not call this method from your code.
This call to BeginInit is nested in a previous call to BeginInit.
Signals the end of the <xref href="System.Windows.Shell.JumpList"></xref> initialization.
The <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList> class implements the <xref:System.ComponentModel.ISupportInitialize> interface to support XAML declaration of a <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList>.
The EndInit method is only called when the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList> is declared in XAML and attached to an <xref:System.Windows.Application> by using the attached property syntax.
You do not call this method from your code.
The EndInit method has the same effect as the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList.Apply%2A> method.
EndInit sends the content of the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList> to the Windows shell in its current state.
After this call is complete, the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList.JumpItems%2A> property is modified to contain only those items that the Windows shell successfully added to its Jump List.
You can access the lists of removed items through event handlers for the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList.JumpItemsRejected> and <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList.JumpItemsRemovedByUser> events.
This call to EndInit is not paired with a call to <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList.BeginInit*>.
Returns the <xref href="System.Windows.Shell.JumpList"></xref> object associated with an application.
You can call the GetJumpList method to get the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList> currently associated with an <xref:System.Windows.Application>.
The .NET Framework does not require that this be the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList> that is currently applied to the Windows shell.
The application associated with the <xref href="System.Windows.Shell.JumpList"></xref>.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Shell.JumpList"></xref> object associated with the specified application.
Gets the collection of <xref href="System.Windows.Shell.JumpItem"></xref> objects that are displayed in the Jump List.
Jump Lists can contain two types of items, a <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> and a <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpPath>.
A <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> is a link to a program and a <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpPath> is a link to a file.
When a <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList> is created, the JumpItems collection is empty.
You can add any <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> or <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpPath> objects to the collection.
The collection will only contain items that have been added by your program.

After the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList> has been passed to the Windows shell by a successful call to either the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList.EndInit%2A> or <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList.Apply%2A> methods, the JumpItems collection will contain only the items that were successfully added to the taskbar Jump List.
Items that were not successfully added are removed from the JumpItems collection.
You can access the lists of removed items through event handlers for the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList.JumpItemsRejected> and <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList.JumpItemsRemovedByUser> events.
The collection of <xref href="System.Windows.Shell.JumpItem"></xref> objects displayed in the Jump List.
The default is an empty collection.
Occurs when jump items are not successfully added to the Jump List by the Windows shell.

After the contents of the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList> are applied to the Windows shell, the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList.JumpItems%2A> property is modified to contain only those items that the Windows shell successfully added to its Jump List.
You can access the lists of removed items through event handlers for the JumpItemsRejected and <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList.JumpItemsRemovedByUser> events.
To be added.
Occurs when jump items previously in the Jump List are removed from the list by the user.

After the contents of the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList> are applied to the Windows shell, the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList.JumpItems%2A> property is modified to contain only those items that the Windows shell successfully added to its Jump List.
You can access the lists of removed items through event handlers for the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList.JumpItemsRejected> and JumpItemsRemovedByUser events.
To be added.
Sets the <xref href="System.Windows.Shell.JumpList"></xref> object associated with an application.
You can create multiple <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList> objects.
However, only one <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList> at a time can be associated with an <xref:System.Windows.Application>.
Call the SetJumpList method to set the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList> currently associated with an <xref:System.Windows.Application>.
The application associated with the <xref href="System.Windows.Shell.JumpList"></xref>.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Shell.JumpList"></xref> to associate with the application.
Gets or sets a value that indicates whether frequently used items are displayed in the Jump List.
The contents of the **Frequent** category are managed by the Windows shell.
To display frequently used items in the Jump List, set the ShowFrequentCategory property to `true`.
The **Recent** and **Frequent** categories often contain many of the same jump items.
As a result, applications typically display either the **Recent** or the **Frequent** category in the Jump List, but not both.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if frequently used items are displayed in the Jump List; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
The default is <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Gets or sets a value that indicates whether recently used items are displayed in the Jump List.
The contents of the **Recent** category are managed by the Windows shell.
To display frequently used items in the Jump List, set the ShowRecentCategory property to `true`.
The **Recent** and **Frequent** categories often contain many of the same jump items.
As a result, applications typically display either the **Recent** or the **Frequent** category in the Jump List, but not both.
You can call the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList.AddToRecentCategory%2A> method to request that the Windows shell add items to the **Recent** items list.

If your application is not registered to handle the file name type of the item, it will not appear in the **Recent** list and calls to <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpList.AddToRecentCategory%2A> will fail silently.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if recently used items are displayed in the Jump List; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
The default is <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
